docs.lead_paragraph: Leading a national surge of second thoughts about managed health care, California, long a pacesetter in the field, has plunged into a wholesale review of its managed-care system, which now covers more than half the state's 32 million people. An avalanche of proposals for tighter government regulation is advancing in the California Legislature. The Governor and legislators have appointed a joint commission to recommend improvements in managed care. And patients are expressing their qualms: State officials registered more than 2,000 consumer complaints about health maintenance organizations last year, an 18 percent increase over 1995.

headline.main: PIONEERING STATE FOR MANAGED CARE CONSIDERS CHANGE

docs.abstract: California, long pace-setter in field of managed care, plunges into wholesale review of its managed-care system, which currently covers more than half of state's 32 million people; avalanche of proposals for tighter government regulation is advancing in Legislature, Governor and legislators have appointed joint commission to recommend improvements, and patients are expressing qualms; growing skepticism is fueled by trend in managed-care industry to reduce health care costs by rejecting treatments it deems not medically necessary; case involving 69-year-old retiree Joyce Ramey, who won $1.1 million in binding arbitration stemming from refusal by Medicare HMO Inter Valley Health Plan Inc to provide kidney dialysis treatments discussed; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A state-subsidized children's insurance program called Children First, envisioned by Governor Whitman 18 months ago, is expected to start in September, officials said last week. But the program, with $5 million in seed money allocated by the Legislature in June, will begin only in a limited way because full financing to cover the 100,000 children eligible remains uncertain.

headline.main: A Small-Scale Start, Perhaps, for a Children's Insurance Program

docs.abstract: Officials say state-subsidized children's insurance program in New Jersey is expected to start in September with coverage offered to parents of 5,000 children; full financing to cover 100,000 eligible children remains uncertain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A BROAD stretch of rolling green, a darting flash of chipmunk, a canopy of branch and leaf that filters out the sun's excess; all recommend themselves sweetly to the senses as one stands at a spot of land along a curve of the Connecticut River in Cromwell. Then there is the sound of a heavy object being violently swung down, followed by an unmistakable human groan. A white ball flies into the air, landing with a sudden splat amid tall grass a few measly yards away. A man wielding a golf club emerges from a rise in the ground, muttering to himself. His three companions manage to avoid eye contact with him as they sit in their carts, waiting to move on.

headline.main: Turning a Flat Public Course Into Golfer's Gem

docs.abstract: Article describes transformation of Tournament Players Club at River Highlands in Cromwell, Conn, from flat public course into one of jewels of Professional Golfers' Assn Tour; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest issues that the House and Senate will have to resolve in the current budget negotiations is whether to raise the age at which Americans are eligible for Medicare. The House chose to keep the age of eligibility at 65, and seems determined to stick to that position. The Senate's plan, on the other hand, calls for raising the age to 67. This proposal creates more problems than it solves. The Senate proposal parallels a scheduled increase in the eligibility age for Social Security benefits. Under this reform, enacted in 1983, the ''normal retirement age'' for Social Security will rise two months a year starting in 2003, until it reaches 66 in 2008. This schedule will be repeated in 2020. By 2025, the normal retirement age will be 67.

headline.main: Two Years That Make a Big Difference

docs.abstract: Robert D Reischauer Op-Ed article holds Senate proposal to raise Medicare eligibility age to 67 creates more problems than it solves; holds plan would be unfair to lower-skilled, lower-paid workers, increase number of uninsured senior citizens, lead employers to cut back retiree health coverage and pass costs to state governments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE woman at my left sighs. ''I wish I could quit my job,'' she tells the hairdresser who is mixing the dye for her foil highlight treatment. ''I would love to stay home with the baby, but it's just financially impossible. How do families on one income do it?'' As a veteran of one-salary living, I have this immediate response: ''Honey, we don't drop $85 on auburn highlights. We schedule the no-frill haircut and save five bucks by skipping the blow-dry.''

headline.main: One Income. One Purpose. Yes, a Family Can Stay Afloat.

docs.abstract: Cynthia Tavlin article on living frugally on single salary to allow family to have stay-at-home parent (M)+

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York City union representing more than 30,000 nursing home and hospital workers is facing a possible takeover by its parent union on charges of financial mismanagement and unauthorized payment of benefits to several individuals. Andrew L. Stern, president of the 1.1-million-member Service Employees International Union, announced last week that the union would hold a hearing on Thursday to determine whether to place New York-based Local 144 under trusteeship.

headline.main: Union Faces A Takeover By Its Parent

docs.abstract: Local 144 of Service Employees International Union, which represents more than 30,000 New York City nursing home and hospital workers, faces possible takeover by its parent union on charges of financial mismanagement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK CITY'S free-market rental fever of a year ago, fueled by tales of 30 percent increases, bidding wars, broken promises and C.I.A.-like credit checks -- many of them true -- has abated. A bit. It's not that rents have plummeted or demand has slackened, as they did during the real estate recession of the early 90's. But a broad-brush portrait of the rental scene would have to be painted in varied shades, with red-hot spots for certain niches of the market, and cooler hues for others.

headline.main: Rental Fever: Temperature Drops -- a Bit

docs.abstract: Median unregulated rent for apartments of all sizes in Manhattan rose 17.3 percent from 1993 to 1996, according to Census Bureau statistics; in Brooklyn, median unregulated rent rose 8.7 percent; median rents for all sizes of apartments in Bronx rose 8.33 percent, and in Queens, increase was 7.69 percent; Staten Island jump was 7.83 percent; in last 12 months, churning of rental market has played out against backdrop of political posturing and fierce infighting over future of rent regulation; photo; map; chart with rent breakdowns by neighborhood (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cameron Tuttle is the author of The Paranoid's Pocket Guide. Q: You recommend niche worrying. What is it? A: Niche worrying is a means of conveniently organizing one's paranoia. It's concentrating on a specific fear or phobia at an appropriate time, like focusing on getting Legionnaires' disease from inhaling steam containing Legionella pneumophila bacteria while taking a shower at the gym.
docs.abstract: Interview with Cameron Tuttle, author of guide for paranoids; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's largest union of hospital workers has proposed an innovative deal that would use at least $100 million from its pension plan to offer early retirement incentives for older workers as a means of guaranteeing job security for younger ones. The union, 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, has made the proposal to Mount Sinai, Columbia-Presbyterian and 28 other nonprofit hospitals because it fears the city's financially squeezed hospitals will make large-scale layoffs when its current contract expires next June 30.

headline.main: Union Plan Sees Buyouts Saving Jobs

docs.lead_paragraph: Rose Associates, among the oldest names in New York City real estate, is the newest player to enter the burgeoning residential scene in downtown Manhattan, converting a 31-story office building at 21 West Street into 293 apartments. The conversion is the first housing project below Eighth Street and the first rental in 10 years for Rose Associates, which over 69 years has built 10,000 apartments, both rentals and condominiums, most of them in Manhattan.

headline.main: Rose Associates Enters The Conversion Market

docs.abstract: Rose Associates, one of oldest names in New York City real estate, will enter residential market in lower Manhattan with conversion of 31-story office building at 21 West Street into 293 apartments; name will be Le Rivage; photo (S)
